I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The proposed knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) is designed to strengthen 
the capacity of national statistics offices (NSOs) in Asia and the Pacific to meet the increasing 
data demands for policy making and monitoring of development goals and targets. It will focus on 
three important areas:1 (i) subnational disaggregation of the Sustainable Development Goals 
(SDGs),2 (ii) enhanced compilation of national accounts and other key economic indicators, and 
(iii) provision of strategic inputs for the modernization of national statistical systems (NSSs) to 
inform policy design and statistical capacity-building initiatives of the global statistical system.  
 
2.  The proposed TA, which is part of the approved 2017 work plan of the Economic Research 
and Regional Cooperation Department (ERCD) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB),3 is linked 
to the Cape Town Global Action Plan for Sustainable Development Data and draft framework of 
ADB’s Strategy 2030.4 Strategy 2030’s strategic business areas section includes “supporting 
SDGs” as a priority under social sector operations.5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) set forth specific, time-bound, and quantified 
targets. The MDGs (i) were useful in assessing how economies of the world fared in addressing 
extreme  poverty  in  its  many  dimensions;  and  (ii)  helped  focus  development  efforts  and 
interventions on countries that fell short of specific development targets, resulting in significant 
gains in most parts of the world. However, the widening gap between the rich and poor in many 
countries suggests that some socioeconomically vulnerable groups have not experienced such 
gains. With the goal of ending all forms of poverty, the SDGs aim to build on the success of the 
MDGs by promoting development among vulnerable groups. 
 
4.  Although the data collected for MDG monitoring allowed tracking of how countries fared 
in terms of different social and economic indicators relative to other countries, they provided 
limited empirical evidence on which segments of a country’s population experienced significant 
progress or lagged in terms of the MDGs. This is problematic because there are limited data to 
guide the design of intervention programs meant to appropriately target the socioeconomically 
vulnerable. In response, the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development has pledged that “no one 
will be left behind”, calling for the development of SDG indicators for different subpopulation 
groups  based  on  income  class,  gender,  ethnicity,  geographic  location,  and  other  relevant 
dimensions. Quality, accessible, timely, and reliable disaggregated data are needed to identify 
subgroups of the population that were left out with respect to specific SDG targets. 
 
5.  In addition to indicators included in the SDG, more disaggregated data on economic 
transactions  by  industry  and  product  are  needed  to  better  understand  the  production, 
consumption, and trade structures of a globalizing world. Compilation of such disaggregated 
economic indicators requires regular estimation (following the 2008 System of National Accounts) 
                                                
1  United Nations Statistics Division (UNSD). 2017. Report of the Secretary-General on statistical capacity building at 
the 48th Session of the United Nations Statistical Commission. New York.  https://unstats.un.org/unsd/statcom/48th-
session/documents/2017-30-CapacityBuilding-E.pdf 
2 United  Nations.  2015.  Transforming  our  world:  the  2030  Agenda  for  Sustainable  Development. 
https://sustainabledevelopment.un.org/post2015/transformingourworld. 
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 5 July 2017. 
4  UNSC. 2017. Cape Town Global Action Plan for Sustainable Development Data. Cape Town. https://unstats.un.org/ 
sdgs/ hlg/Cape-Town-Global-Action-Plan/ 
5  ADB. 2017. Framework for Strategy 2030. Manila (25 January). 
  https://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/page/181506/Framework-for-Strategy-2030_25Jan2017-v2.pdf.

2 
of high-quality national accounts statistics and supply and use tables.6 Further, many developing 
member countries (DMCs) require standard accounting frameworks detailing the links between 
economic activities and social and environmental consequences to illuminate policy issues and 
to track the progress towards several SDGs. 
 
6.  NSOs and other public entities play a critical role in the production and dissemination of 
official statistics. The statistics are usually compiled using conventional sources, including sample 
surveys, censuses, and administrative sources. The rise of innovative data sources such as big 
data allows for more inclusive and networked problem solving.7  However, many DMC NSOs 
require critical and specific TA in developing or enhancing technical skills and infrastructure for 
producing and disseminating data using conventional and innovative sources. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: improved data monitoring for evidence-based 
policy  making  and  public  sector  management.  The  TA  will  have  the  following  outcome: 
strengthened capacity of NSOs to provide relevant disaggregated data for policy design and 
targeted interventions to support vulnerable groups.8  
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
8.  Output 1:  Technical manual on disaggregation of official statistics, knowledge- 
sharing workshops, and case studies on various applications of innovative data analytics 
for disaggregation of select Sustainable Development Goal indicators. The TA will facilitate 
a series of strategically designed training workshops and course modules on disaggregation of 
official statistics and SDG indicators targeted to NSOs of about 10 DMCs. Initially, the project 
team will prepare a manual that will take stock of various methods of small area estimation (SAE).9 
The manual will also cover (i) ways of using innovative data sources, e.g.,  satellite images, mobile 
data, or social media data to produce disaggregated data for official statistics; and (ii) relevant 
issues related to the use of these data.10 The project team will use the results of these activities 
to carefully design the conferences, training workshops and course modules. Lastly, two country 
case studies on a specific policy-relevant issue showcasing specific applications of SAE and 
innovative data analytics to disaggregate select SDG indicators will be prepared. 
 
9.  Output  2:  Targeted  knowledge-sharing  workshops  and  training  on  enhanced 
compilation of national accounts and other economic indicators. The project team will 
                                                
6  The System of National Accounts refers to the internationally agreed standard set of recommendations on how to 
compile various measures of economic activity. The supply and use table is a statistical table that summarizes the 
relationship between inputs, outputs, product supply, and demand across different economic sectors. (UNSD. 2018. 
System of National Accounts 2008. New York. https://unstats.un.org/unsd/nationalaccount/sna2008.asp)  
7  Big data generally refer to the type of data arising from people’s digital transactions with computers, social media, 
mobile phones, photos, satellite images, sensors, and other types of digital technology. 
8  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
9  SAE is a class of statistical techniques that are designed to provide reliable estimates of specific characteristics of 
subpopulation groups with small sample sizes in surveys. 
10 Existing applications of big data are useful in disaggregating official statistics that are traditionally produced using 
conventional data. For example, daytime satellite images of houses’ roofs have been used to estimate village-level 
poverty rates in African countries. In other countries, satellite images of nighttime lights have been used to estimate 
the magnitude of economic activity (e.g., gross domestic product) and population size at more granular levels. Mobile 
phone records have been used to derive local-level estimates of migration and access to financial services.

3 
 
provide technical training programs on compiling and analyzing components of the national 
accounts that are critical to the sustainability and development of the economic statistical systems 
of selected DMCs. The project team will provide training programs and knowledge-sharing 
workshops to NSO staff on (i) instituting and operationalizing statistical business registers (the 
specialized infrastructure required for the production and analysis of multisourced economic data 
feeding into national accounts); (ii) producing high-quality statistics and analysis on economies’ 
participation in international production-sharing arrangements or global value chains; and (iii) 
developing a suite of (a) innovative socioeconomic data compilation and analysis frameworks 
comprised of extended supply and use tables, (b) extended input–output tables, and (c) social 
accounting matrixes, which facilitate static and dynamic analysis and impact and policy analysis 
of the economy and its interaction with the environment and society. 
 
10.  Output 3: High-level regional conference and workshops in preparation for the 
updating of the Handbook of Statistical Organizations. The TA will finance a conference 
and/or other workshops to be organized for high-level dialogues with senior management of 
selected NSOs in Asia and the Pacific and leading experts on thematic areas such as (i) quality, 
communication, and partnership; (ii) statistical architecture for an integrated production system; 
(iii) information technology; (iv) capacity building; and (v) resource mobilization relevant to the 
operation and organization of NSSs. Similar conferences and workshops are planned in other 
regions of the world, which will be supported by other regional and international agencies. The 
thematic conferences will serve as forums for in-depth discussions and provide comprehensive 
inputs to the updating of the Handbook of Statistical Organizations, which will be undertaken by 
the United Nations Statistics Division (UNSD).11 
 
11.  Output 4: Working paper and/or policy notes identifying other methodological and 
substantive  areas  where  developing  member  countries’  national  statistical  systems’ 
capacity needs to be strengthened. Modernizing NSSs will entail numerous enhancements to 
the existing operational framework of NSOs and other government agencies with data collection 
functions. The first three outputs of this TA will address only a few of the immediate priorities of 
DMC NSOs, so commitment from international development organizations to strengthen the 
capacity of NSSs is imperative. The TA presents an opportunity to explore how ADB can facilitate 
continued engagement and collaborative statistical work with NSOs in Asia and the Pacific. 
 
C.   Cost and Financing 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6). The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 
2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  ADB, through its Development Economics and Indicators Division (ERDI) of the ERCD, 
will be the executing agency for this TA. ERDI will work closely with relevant ADB departments, 
including the (i) Department of External Relations regarding workshops and trainings and the 
publication of knowledge products; (ii) Office of Information Systems and Technology regarding 
procurement of equipment, software, and other needs of the TA related to information technology; 
                                                
11 The updating of the Handbook (which outlines the general principles of the operation and organization of a statistical 
agency) and conferences for NSO senior staff are in line with the United Nations Statistical Commission’s strategies 
in relation to the provision of strategic guidance to (i) achieve more modern, integrated, and coordinated NSSs; and 
(ii) ensure that there is a standards-based architecture that allows for more effective response to the SDGs’ data 
requirements.

4 
(iii) Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department; (iv) Strategy, Policy and Review 
Department (as focal point of the SDGs) regarding TA activities to promote synergy with existing 
SDG-related initiatives of other ADB departments with other regional and international agencies; 
and (v) regional departments.

a NSOs will be the main implementing agencies of the country-specific studies described under output 1 and activities

Source: ADB. 
 
14.  ERDI will implement all activities relating to knowledge-sharing workshops, training, and 
preparation of technical reports under the TA while the NSOs will be the national implementing 
agencies for all country-specific case studies under output 1 and activities under output 2.12 No 
activity will be financed in any participating DMC unless a no-objection letter is obtained from the 
DMC government.13 The project team will undertake the overall implementation of activities under 
                                                
12 The project team will explore possible collaboration with experts from Pulse Lab Jakarta, Statistics Korea, UN Global 
Pulse, United Nations Development Programme, UNSD, UNESCAP, the World Bank, and other development 
partners. Specifically, the project team may invite experts from these agencies as resource persons. The project 
team will also explore the possibility of joint publications with these organizations. If this planned collaboration were 
to evolve into a knowledge partnership, the staff instruction on business processes for knowledge partnerships under 
TA operations will be followed. 
13 In addition to no-objection letters, ADB and the participating DMCs will sign a framework of partnership, which is a 
nonlegal yet formal document that outlines the detailed roles and responsibilities of ADB and participating DMCs, 
and the schedule of key milestones and activities. A draft framework of partnership will be provided to ADB’s Office 
of the General Counsel and other relevant departments for review prior to signing by both parties. For output 1, the 
choice of NSOs will based on the following criteria: NSO should (i) be currently developing SDG data compilation 
framework, which identifies disaggregation of select SDG indicators as one of its core priorities; (ii) have access to 
relevant micro-level records of survey, census, administrative data, and/or a specific type of innovative data source 
that are either publicly accessible or can be made accessible to the TA; and (iii) have a dedicated pool of staff who 
can be trained in the use of SAE techniques and innovative data sources, and who preferably have experience on 
related initiatives such as poverty mapping. The same set of criteria applies to the selection of NSOs for output 2.

5 
 
output 3 in close collaboration with the UNSD, which is responsible for updating the Handbook of 
Statistical Organizations, and with regional partners such as the United Nations Economic and 
Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific (UNESCAP), and countries in the region.14 The project 
team will implement all TA activities from September 2017 to March 2021.  
 
15.  Under outputs 1 and 2, each participating economy that will conduct country-specific case 
studies will be required to identify a national coordinator who will be responsible for implementing 
the scheduled activities at the country level in accordance with the approved schedule of activities. 
The ADB project team will undertake periodic reviews of progress and necessary interventions in 
the form of technical and operational advice that will be provided on an ongoing basis. The ADB 
project team will also conduct biannual workshops with project staff of all participating economies 
to review progress of data collection, methodological development, and identification of data 
quality issues. 
  
16.  Consulting services. The TA will finance 157 person-months of consulting services (8 
person-months international and 149 person-months national) and one person-month of resource 
person inputs. ADB will engage the consultants on an individual basis in accordance with the 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time).15 Lump sum 
payments and output-based contracts will be considered for consulting services.  
 
17.  ADB’s procurement. Procurement of equipment, computer hardware, and software will 
follow ADB's Procurement Guidelines. Equipment purchased will comply with Administrative 
Order 4.02 under ADB’s 2008 Asset Management and Inventory Control on Accountability of 
Assets Purchased under TA.16 The disposal and/or turnover of procured equipment will follow the 
procedures as per relevant project administration instructions. Disbursements under the TA will 
be done in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
amended from time to time). The TA requires use of micro and macro data; these will be procured 
from DMC agencies, other research institutions, and private firms through the single-source 
selection method. For equipment such as laptop computers and software, procurement will use 
the shopping method. 
 
18.  Social media and websites.  ERDI will develop a publicly accessible website that will 
serve as a central repository for all its statistical capacity initiatives. Online training modules and 
other training materials produced through the TA will be uploaded to this website. ERDI will 
maintain the website in close coordination with the Department of External Relations and the 
Office of Information Systems and Technology. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis for 
Data for Development, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
                                                
14 All regional events to be conducted as part of output 3 will be implemented in collaboration with DMCs, the UNSD, 
regional agencies such as UNESCAP, partners of the memorandum of understanding group on statistical activities 
of the multilateral development banks which comprises the African Development Bank, ADB, Inter-American 
Development Bank, International Monetary Fund, Islamic Development Bank, World Bank and the United Nations. 
The objective of this group is to enhance collaboration in strengthening the statistical capacity of Member States.  
15 The consultants should be experts in big data analysis, SAE, or social and/or economic statistics compilation. Terms 
of Reference for Consultants are accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3. 
16 ADB. 2016. Asset Management and Inventory Control. Administrative Orders. AO 4.02. Manila.

Key Activities with Milestones 
Output 1: Technical manual on disaggregation of official statistics, knowledge-sharing workshops, 
and case studies on various applications of innovative data analytics for disaggregation of select 
SDG indicators 
1.1  Conduct desk research to take stock of previous and existing initiatives on disaggregation of official 
statistics and available types of data sources (Q4 2017) 
1.2  Conduct inception workshop (Q2 2018) 
1.3  Identify DMCs, hold preliminary meetings with the identified DMCs, and sign No-Objection Letters (Q3 
2018)  
1.4  Review and acquire of relevant data sources (Q4 2018) 
1.5  Prepare technical report and online training modules on SAE and other statistical methodologies for 
disaggregating official statistics (Q4 2017–Q4 2018) 
1.6  Prepare an assessment report on the challenges and opportunities of using innovative data sources 
for compilation of official statistics in Asia and the Pacific (Q4 2017–Q4 2018) 
1.7  Conduct training workshops on SAE techniques (Q3 2018–Q2 2019)

8  Appendix 1 
1.8  Process, analyze, and implement SAE techniques using conventional and innovative data sources (Q3 
2018–Q3 2019) 
1.9 Data validation and drafting of country reports on application of specific SAE techniques and big data 
(Q3 2018–Q4 2020) 
1.10 Publish country reports on application of specific SAE techniques and big data (Q4 2020) 
 
Output 2: Targeted knowledge-sharing workshops and training on enhanced compilation of national 
accounts and other economic indicators 
2.1 Assess the participating DMCs' statistical information requirements, statistical infrastructure, data 
sources, and capacity (Q1 2018–Q2 2018)  
2.2 Customize, deploy, and operationalize the ADB SBR system to suit economy specific requirements (Q3 
2018–Q2 2019)  
2.3 Organize training for participating DMCs on the theory and concepts related to SNA, trade statistics, 
input-output  analysis,  TiVA  estimation,  GVC  analysis,  national  accounts,  statistics  on  economic 
globalization, extended national economic accounts, and SBRs (Q1 2018–Q2 2018)  
2.4 Organize training for participating DMCs on the operation and maintenance of ADB SBR system (Q1 
2019–Q2 2019) 
2.5 Develop and review the sequence of accounts, datasets, statistics and indicators for multiple reference 
years (Q3 2018–Q3 2020)  
2.6 Draft country-specific analytical report based on the time-series developed (Q4 2020)  
2.7 Release of the online courses and training manuals (Q4 2020) 
 
Output 3: High-level regional conference and workshops, in preparation for the updating of the 
Handbook of Statistical Organizations 
3.1 Coordinate with UNSC and regional partners regarding the work plan for the regional conferences and 
workshops (Q1 2018)  
3.2 Coordinate with DMCs regarding organization and participation in regional conferences and workshops 
(Q3 2019) 
3.3 Organize regional conferences and workshops (Q2 2018–Q3 2019) 
 
Output 4: Working paper and/or policy notes identifying other methodological and substantive areas 
where DMCs’ national statistical systems’ capacity needs to be strengthened 
4.1 Conduct needs assessment study (Q1 2020) 
4.2 Prepare draft report (Q2 2020) 
4.3 Prepare final report (Q3 2020) 
TA Management Activities 
Engage consultants (international, national) (Q4 2017–Q2 2018) 
Conduct regular WebEx/Skype meetings with development partners (Q1 2018–Q4 2020) 
TA Physical and Financial closing (Q1–Q2 2021) 
TA Completion Report (Q3 2021) 
 
Inputs 
ADB:      $1,000,000 (TASF 6) 
Assumptions for Partner Financing 
Not applicable. 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, DMC = developing member country, FOP = framework of partnership, NSO = 
national statistics office, Q = quarter, SAE = small area estimation, SBR = statistical business register, SDG = 
Sustainable Development Goal, SNA = System of National Accounts, TA = technical assistance, TASF = Technical 
Assistance Special Fund, UNSC = United Nations Statistical Commission. 
Source: ADB.

3.  Surveys  20.0 
4.  Goods (rental or purchase)   35.0 
5.  Training, seminars, workshops, forum, and conferences   
a.  Resource persons and facilitators  10.0 
b.  Travel cost of Asian Development Bank staff acting as resource  40.0 
person 
c.  Venue rental and related facilities  40.0 
d.  Participants  290.0 
e.  Representation  10.0 
6.  Contingencies  60.0 
Total  1,000.0 
a  Financed by the Asian Development Bank’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6). 
b  Includes airfare and miscellaneous travel expenses and shall be implemented in accordance with the memo “Travel 
expenses of consultants under TA and Government Officials in connection with Non-member countries” dated 29 
October 2013.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  ERCD  –  Economic Research and Regional Cooperation Department 
  ERDI  –  Development Economics and Indicators Division 
  MDG  –  Millennium Development Goal 
  NSS  –  national statistical system 
  NSO  –  national statistics office 
  SAE  –  small area estimation 
  SDG  –  Sustainable Development Goal 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  UNESCAP  –  United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia 
and the Pacific 
  UNSD  –  United Nations Statistics Division 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to United States dollars unless otherwise stated.  
 
Vice-President  B. Susantono, Knowledge Management and Sustainable 
Development  
Chief Economist and  Y. Sawada, Economic Research and Regional Cooperation 
Director General  Department (ERCD)

In preparing any country program or strategy, financing any project, or by making any designation 
of  or  reference  to  a  particular  territory  or  geographic  area  in  this  document,  the  Asian

territory or area.
